coredata.dc:title: Kinetics and mechanism of ozonation to treat Microcystis-laden source waters affected by cell-viability
coredata.dc:creator: Li, Xi
Song, Weijun
Chen, Sheng
coredata.dc:description: Toxic cyanobacteria are challenging drinking water safety globally, and their cell-viability declines at decay stage of a succussive bloom. Ozone might be a more effective oxidant to treat both high- and low-viability cyanobacteria than other common oxidants (e.g., chlorine, potassium permanganate). However, previous studies only conducted ozonation experiments using high-viability cyanobacteria, and potential influences of cell-viability on ozonation process, remains unknown. In this study, kinetics of ozone decay, cell inactivation, membrane destruction, and cyanotoxin fate of high- and low-viability Microcystis (the most common genus), was investigated, and associated mechanism was discussed. Results showed that low-viability Microcystis exhibited a higher rate constant of membrane destruction (665–744 M−1 s−1) than high-viability Microcystis (364–600 M−1 s−1) by equal concentrations of ozone, ascribed to loosely gelatinous sheath comprised with fewer organic matters as oxidant scavengers. Meanwhile, a higher rate constant of photosynthetic inactivation induced by ozonation, was observed for low-viability Microcystis (312–364 M−1 s−1) than that for high-viability Microcystis (168–294 M−1 s−1). However, elevated aromatic organics competitively inhibited microcystin ozonation for low-viability Microcystis, and hydroxyl radicals for microcystin oxidation could be reduced by elevated organic loads and alkalinity. Moreover, elevated ozone exposure (>51 mg min L−1) did not totally oxidize microcystin with a residual of 30 μg L−1 for low-viability Microcystis. These findings suggested that elevated microcystin risk would be the great barrier to limit ozonation application for low-viability Microcystis, even with benefits of higher cell inactivation compared to high-viability Microcystis.

slow = rate constant of ozone decay for slow reaction; R2: correlation coefficients of this model; RSS: residual sum of squares of this model.

Concentrations of dissolved organic matters (DOC), UV254, and alkalinity of Microcystis-laden source waters dominated by high- and low-viability Microcystis, respectively.

Observation of gelatinous sheath of high- and low-viability Microcystis by SEM (a), and total concentrations of organic matters comprised for gelatinous sheath, extracted from high- and low-viability Microcystis (b).

head.ce:title: Kinetics and mechanism of ozonation to treat Microcystis-laden source waters affected by cell-viability

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Toxic cyanobacteria are challenging drinking water safety globally, and their cell-viability declines at decay stage of a succussive bloom. Ozone might be a more effective oxidant to treat both high- and low-viability cyanobacteria than other common oxidants (e.g., chlorine, potassium permanganate). However, previous studies only conducted ozonation experiments using high-viability cyanobacteria, and potential influences of cell-viability on ozonation process, remains unknown. In this study, kinetics of ozone decay, cell inactivation, membrane destruction, and cyanotoxin fate of high- and low-viability Microcystis (the most common genus), was investigated, and associated mechanism was discussed. Results showed that low-viability Microcystis exhibited a higher rate constant of membrane destruction (665–744 M−1 s−1) than high-viability Microcystis (364–600 M−1 s−1) by equal concentrations of ozone, ascribed to loosely gelatinous sheath comprised with fewer organic matters as oxidant scavengers. Meanwhile, a higher rate constant of photosynthetic inactivation induced by ozonation, was observed for low-viability Microcystis (312–364 M−1 s−1) than that for high-viability Microcystis (168–294 M−1 s−1). However, elevated aromatic organics competitively inhibited microcystin ozonation for low-viability Microcystis, and hydroxyl radicals for microcystin oxidation could be reduced by elevated organic loads and alkalinity. Moreover, elevated ozone exposure (>51 mg min L−1) did not totally oxidize microcystin with a residual of 30 μg L−1 for low-viability Microcystis. These findings suggested that elevated microcystin risk would be the great barrier to limit ozonation application for low-viability Microcystis, even with benefits of higher cell inactivation compared to high-viability Microcystis.

ce:data-availability.ce:para: Data will be made available on request.

ce:section.ce:para: Cyanobacterial proliferation is posing a great challenge for safe drinking water (He et al., 2016; Griffith and Gobler, 2020). For instance, excessive cyanobacterial biomass in source waters can result in coagulation inhibition, clarification disruption, and filter clogging in drinking water treatments plants (DWTPs), and algal organic matters (AOMs) as precursors, can induce the formation of disinfection by-products (DBPs) after chlorination (He et al., 2016). Moreover, several cyanobacterial species are potent producers of cyanotoxins, and their health effects for humans have been well studied, including gastroenteritis, liver damage, and neurotoxicity etc. (Merel et al., 2013). In the past 20 years, some drinking water crisis resulted from cyanotoxins, have been recorded (Huisman et al., 2018). For example, in August 2014, a “do not drink” advisory was issued for Toledo (Ohio, USA), leading to over 400,000 people being without tap water for nearly 48 h, since microcystins (MCs) exceeded WHO guideline value for safe drinking water (Bullerjahn et al., 2016). World Health Organization (WHO) has set a provisional Drinking Water Guideline of 1 μg L−1 for microcystin-LR (MC-LR) (WHO, 2014). Hence, effective control of cyanobacteria and cyanotoxins is quite important to ensure drinking water safety.

In DWTPs, pre-, inter-, and post-oxidation process have been employed to remove cyanobacteria and undesirable metabolites (e.g., cyanotoxins), and ozone, chlorine, and potassium permanganate are the most common oxidants (Maatouk et al., 2002; Plummer and Edzwald, 2002; Chen and Yeh, 2005 ;; Chen et al., 2009 ;; Hurtado et al., 2008; Ma et al., 2012; Zamyadi et al., 2015, 2019; Barešová et al., 2020; Greenstein et al., 2020; Qi et al., 2021; Xu et al., 2022). Recent ecological studies revealed that cyanobacterial blooms are a successive process in natural freshwaters, including development, maintenance, and decay stages, and this process is mainly driven by the life cycle of cyanobacterial cells (exponential-stationary-decline) (Wilhelm et al., 2020) (Fig. S1). Among the three stages, cell-viability of cyanobacteria at decay stage is much lower than that at development and maintenance stages (Li et al., 2020), and organic loads of source waters dominated by low-viability cyanobacteria, strikingly increased (Li et al., 2020), which could challenge oxidation process. To optimize oxidation process to treat low-viability cyanobacteria, Li et al., (2020, 2021) conducted chlorination and permanganate oxidation to treat low-viability Microcystis (the most problematic genus). Results found that chlorination caused elevated microcystin risk for low-viability Microcystis, ascribed to the changed kinetics of microcystin release (ki) and degradation (ke) (ki >ke) (Li et al., 2020). Low concentration of potassium permanganate (<2 mg L−1) could degrade extracellular microcystin to some degrees, but residual microcystin was reaching up to about 10–40 μg L−1 due to the decrease of microcystin oxidation efficiency (Li et al., 2021). High concentration of potassium permanganate (>10 mg L−1) eliminated cyanotoxin risk but color issue resulted from manganese ion residual occurred (Li et al., 2021). Overall, chlorine and potassium permanganate did not perform well to treat low-viability Microcystis.

In contrast to chlorine and potassium permanganate, ozone held a higher oxidative capacity to destroy Microcystis cells and microcystin (Rositano et al., 1998; Hitzfeld et al., 2000; Rodríguez et al., 2007 ;; Ding et al., 2010; Fan et al., 2013; Wert et al., 2013, 2014; Li et al., 2018). For example, a much higher rate constant of microcystin-LR degradation by ozonation (4.1 ×105 M−1 s−1) was reported than that by chlorination (33 M−1 s−1) and potassium permanganate oxidation (357 M−1 s−1) (pH=8.0; 25 °C) (Rodríguez et al., 2007). These finding indicated that ozone might be a more effective oxidant to treat low-viability Microcystis. However, it could not be ignored that ozonation could be accelerated or inhibited by organic matters and alkalinity (Hitzfeld et al., 2000; Rositano et al., 2001; Brooke et al., 2006; Onstad et al., 2007; Coral et al., 2013). Li et al., (2020, 2021) demonstrated that changed water matrix (e.g., organic matters) dominated by low-viability Microcystis, resulted in different kinetics of oxidant decay, membrane integrity, and microcystin fate treated by chlorine and potassium permanganate, compared to high-viability Microcystis. These findings suggested that kinetics of ozonation might be also strongly affected by the decrease of cell-viability of Microcystis at decay stage of a successive bloom. Consequently, it was essential to compare kinetics of ozonation to treat high- and low-viability Microcystis.

To our knowledge, some studies have conducted ozonation to treat high-viability cyanobacteria (Table S1), but no studies have systematically compared ozonation to treat high- and low-viability cyanobacteria. In this study, a successive bloom was simulated in lab-scale, and high- and low-viability Microcystis (the most common genus) were collected for ozonation experiments. Kinetics of oxidant decay, photosynthetic inactivation, membrane destruction, and microcystin fate of high- and low-viability Microcystis, was investigated, and associated mechanism was discussed. This study aimed to elucidate how cell-viability of Microcystis could affect ozonation process, and certify the effectiveness of ozonation to treat both high- and low-viability Microcystis. These results would provide an important reference of ozonation to treat Microcystis-laden source water dominated by high- and low-viability Microcystis during a successive bloom by water suppliers.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Preparing samples of high- and low-viability Microcystis
ce:section.ce:para: Microcystis is the most common genus, which has recorded blooms in at least 108 countries (Harke et al., 2016). Herein, a toxic strain Microcystis aeruginosa FACHB-915 was employed to conduct ozonation experiments, purchased from Institute of Hydrobiology, Chinese Academy of Sciences (Li et al., 2020, 2021). To prepare samples of high- and low-viability Microcystis, a successive Microcystis bloom was simulated for 120 d in eutrophic BG-11 medium, including classical development, maintenance, and decay stages (Li et al., 2020a). Cell-density of Microcystis could strongly affect ozonation process (Rositano et al., 1998; Hoeger et al., 2002; Coral et al., 2013), and thus, the same cell-density (1.0 ×106 cells mL−1) of high- and low-viability Microcystis were prepared at development (15 d) and decay stages (100 d) (Fig. S2), and more details were described by Li et al., (2020, 2021).

These samples contained in situ extracellular organic matters (EOMs) produced by high- and low-viability Microcystis, and it could better reflect associated effects of organic loads to treat Microcystis-laden source waters by ozonation, in similar with chlorination and potassium permanganate experiments by Li et al., (2020, 2021). Prior to ozonation experiments, water matrix of Microcystis-laden source waters dominated by high- and low-viability Microcystis, including concentration of organic matters, aromaticity, and alkalinity, were analyzed, since ozonation could be accelerated or inhibited by these factors (Hitzfeld et al., 2000; Rositano et al., 2001; Brooke et al., 2006; Onstad et al., 2007; Coral et al., 2013). Besides, cellular surfaces could protect Microcystis cells from ozone attack (Li et al., 2014), and thus, cellular surface structures and organics concentration of high- and low-viability Microcystis were further analyzed.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Ozonation experiments to treat high- and low-viability Microcystis
ce:section.ce:para: Previous studies revealed that pH could strikingly affect ozonation process (Rositano et al., 2001; Rodríguez et al., 2007). Some studies have done ozonation experiments to treat high-viability Microcystis at pH of 6.0–8.0 (Table S1), and pH values of Microcystis-laden source waters were always above 8.0 during a bloom (Visser et al., 2016). Thus, high- and low-viability Microcystis samples were adjusted to pH 8.0 ± 0.5 using 0.1 M sodium hydroxide or hydrochloric acid before ozonation experiments. Moreover, temperature could strongly affect ozonation to degrade cyanotoxins (e.g., microcystin-LR) (Momania et al., 2008), and the majority of ozonation experiments were conducted at about 20 °C (Table S1). Thus, ozonation experiments for high- and low-viability Microcystis were conducted at the same temperature of about 20 °C, aiming to minimize the effects of temperature on ozonation.

Ozone gas was generated using an ozone generator, running on pure oxygen (Hangzhou Rongxin Electronic Equipment Co., Ltd, China). An ozone stock solution was prepared by dissolving gaseous ozone in cold ultrapure waters. Generally, ozone concentration of < 2 mg L−1 was often used as a pre-oxidant in DWTPs, aiming to reduce negative effects for water quality (e.g., metabolites release, DBPs formation) (Table S1). However, when cyanobacteria-laden source waters held high organic loads, higher ozone concentrations of 3–7 mg L−1, were also employed to inactive cyanobacterial cells and degrade cyanotoxins (Table S1). Source waters dominated by low-viability Microcystis held higher organic loads than that by high-viability Microcystis (Li et al., 2020). Herine, ozone stock solution was added to treat high- and low-viability Microcystis samples with final concentrations of 1, 2, 4, and 8 mg L−1. All ozonation experiments with 2 L reaction suspension were conducted in 5 L glass conical flasks and incubated in darkness. Three parallel ozonation experiments were conducted. During ozonation, these Microcystis samples were taken at specified contact time (0, 1, 2, 5, 8, 10, 15, and 30 min), and ozone residual was immediately quantified. At each time interval, high-purity nitrogen after 5 min was used to remove unreacted ozone, and prepared for the following analysis of membrane integrity, photosynthetic activity, and cyanotoxin quantification. Meanwhile, Microcystis samples without adding ozone were conducted as negative control tests.

During ozonation process, Microcystis cells were removed via a 0.45 µm glass fiber membrane (Millipore, USA), and ozone concentration was quantified using an indigo colorimetric assay (Brooke et al., 2006). Membrane integrity was determined using a flow cytometer (FlowSight, Merck Millipore, USA), as described by Li et al. (2020) . Prior to analysis, Microcystis samples of 200 µL were incubated for 10 min under darkness after adding SYTOX Green nucleic acid stain with a final concentration of 100 nM, and about 10000 cells were measured by FCM, and these data was analyzed using flow cytometric analysis software (Merck Millipore, USA). Photosynthetic activity was measured using PHYTO-PAM phytoplankton analyzer (Walz, Germany) (Li et al., 2020), and photosynthetic yield (φPSII) was employed to characterize their cell activity, according to Maxwell and Johnson (2000).

This strain only produces microcystin-LR (MC-LR) (Li et al., 2020). Before microcystin-LR quantification, high- and low-viability Microcystis samples of 100 mL were taken at each time interval of ozonation experiments. Samples of 50 mL were centrifuged by 6000 g for 5 min to collect Microcystis cells for intracellular microcystin-LR measurements, and the remaining volume of 50 mL was for total microcystin-LR measurements (Fan et al., 2014; Li et al., 2020). A high-performance liquid chromatography system (Agilent 1200, USA) was employed for total/extracellular MC-LR quantification, and C18 solid-phase extraction (SPE) with supelcleanTM ENVITM-18 column was used to concentrate and purify these microcystin samples, as the same protocols by Li et al. (2020, 2021) .

ce:section.ce:section-title: Kinetics modeling for ozonation to treat high- and low-viability Microcystis

ce:section.ce:para:
Ozone decay showed a fast-slow decay for both high- and low-viability Microcystis, in similar with chlorination (Li et al., 2020). A parallel first-order reaction was employed to fit the fast-slow process of ozone decay, as the same model used for chlorination (Daly et al., 2007; Li et al., 2020). Their rate constants of k
fast and k
slow were estimated, according to Eq. (1).

where t = contact time; O(t) = residual ozone concentration at any time t; Ofast = ozone demand of fast reaction; Oslow = ozone demand of slow reaction; k
fast = rate constant of rapid reaction; k
slow = rate constant of slow reaction; Ov.slow = amount of ozone that was not reacted by fast or slow reaction.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Kinetics of membrane destruction and cell inactivation
ce:section.ce:para:
During ozonation to treat high- and low-viability Microcystis, a modifiedChick/Watsonmodel was used to estimate rate constants of photosynthetic inactivation (k
inactive ) and membrane destruction (k
loss ) over oxidant exposure (Wert et al., 2013; Li et al., 2018). The fitted equation was shown (Eq. (2)):

ce:section.ce:section-title: Kinetics of microcystin release and degradation
ce:section.ce:para:
During ozonation, microcystin release and degradation was a consecutive reaction. Concentration of intracellular (A) and extracellular microcystin (B) were described by Eqs. (4) and (5), and their rate constants of intracellular microcystin release (k
i ) and extracellular microcystin degradation (k
e ) were estimated (Jones, 1970; Zamyadi et al., 2013; Fan et al., 2014; Li et al., 2020, 2021).

where ct = ozone exposure; A0 = concentration of intracellular microcystin at t = 0 min; A = concentration of intracellular microcystin at a given ct value; B0 = concentration of extracellular microcystin at t = 0 min; B = concentration of extracellular microcystin at a given ct value; k
i = rate constant of intracellular microcystin release; k
e = rate constant of extracellular microcystin degradation; C = concentration of degraded microcystin at a given ct value.

All ozonation experiments for high- and low-viability Microcystis were conducted in triplicates, and thus, average value and their standard deviation of ozone residual concentration, percentage of intact Microcystis cells, photosynthetic activity, and total/extracellular microcystin-LR concentration treated by ozonation at each time interval, were calculated via equations of AVERAGE and STDEV. Error bars in the plots of figures showed the standard deviation (SD) values of all experimental data. Significant difference of oxidant decay, photosynthetic inactivation, membrane destruction, microcystin release and degradation and their rate constants of high- and low-viability Microcystis were analyzed using Student’s t-test. Results were significant at the 95% level (P < 0.05).

A parallel first-order and a modifiedChick/Watsonmodels were used to fit the process of oxidant decay, photosynthetic inactivation, and membrane destruction of high- and low-viability Microcystis, respectively, and R2 (correlation coefficients) and RSS (residual sum of squares) were calculated for these models. The value of R2 was ranged of [0,1], and reflected fitting performance. If its value was closer to 1, the model fitted better. The value of RSS was ranged of [0,+ ∞), and showed the reliability of this model for these data. The model fitted better if its value was closer to 0. Besides, Nash-Sutcliffe efficiency coefficient (NSE) was employed to determine the performance metric for a consecutive reaction of microcystin fate of high- and low-viability Microcystis, and described the amount of the variance in the data that was explained by this model. For example, 0.90 showed that 90% of the variance in the data was explained by the model, 1 showed that 100% of the data explained by the model. If the number was less than 0, it showed that the data was not explained well by the model. All statistical analyses were performed using Origin 8.0 or Excel 2019.

Ozone decay showed the same fast-slow pattern for both high- and low-viability Microcystis ( Fig. 1). For high-viability Microcystis, initial concentrations of ozone (1 and 2 mg L−1) decreased to below detection limits with a contact time of 15–30 min whist about 0.7 and 4.3 mg L−1 of ozone was present at 30 min with initial concentrations of 4 and 8 mg L−1 (Fig. 1). For low-viability Microcystis, there was no oxidant residual with initial concentrations of 1, 2, and 4 mg L−1, but about 1.7 mg L−1 of oxidant was present at 30 min with an initial ozonation of 8 mg L−1 (Fig. 1).

Rate constants of k
fast and k
slow were estimated via a parallel first-order model (Fig. 1). Fig. 1 showed that this model fitted this process well with R2 values of 0.99–1.00 and RSS values of 0.002–3.87. The k
fast (1.41–1.68 min−1) of low-viability Microcystis was much higher than that of high-viability Microcystis (0.81–0.91 min−1) treated by equal initial concentrations of ozonation (P < 0.05), but there was no significant difference of k
slow between high- and low-viability Microcystis in these treatments (P > 0.05) (Fig. 1).

Ozonation of 1, 2, 4 and 8 mg L−1, could effectively destroy membrane integrity of both high- and low-viability Microcystis (Fig. S3). Among these treatments, initial low concentration of 1 mg L−1 only impaired about 40% loss of membrane integrity, but 92–100% of membrane destruction was observed for high- and low-viability Microcystis with elevated ozonation of 2, 4 and 8 mg L−1 (Fig. S3).

A modifiedChick/Watsonmodel was employed to fit membrane destruction of high-and low-viability Microcystis, and it could work well with values of R2 (0.80–0.96) and RSS (0.005–4.5) ( Fig. 2). Fig. 2 showed that values of k
loss (665–744 M−1 s−1) for low-viability Microcystis remained higher than that for high-viability Microcystis (364–600 M−1 s−1) treated by equal concentrations of ozonation (P < 0.05) (Fig. 2).

Ozonation of 1 and 2 mg L−1 induced about 20% and 70% loss of photosynthetic activity of high- and low-viability Microcystis, and 100% loss was observed with elevated ozonation of 4 and 8 mg L−1 (Fig. S4). Rate constants of photosynthetic inactivation (k
inactive ) were estimated via a modifiedChick/Watsonmodel, and it could work well with values of R2 (0.84–0.99) and RSS (0.003–9.48) ( Fig. 3). Fig. 3 showed that values of k
inactive (312–364 M−1 s−1) for low-viability Microcystis was higher than that for high-viability Microcystis (168–294 M−1 s−1) treated by equal initial concentrations of ozonation (1, 2, 4 and 8 mg L−1) (P < 0.05) (Fig. 3).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Kinetics of microcystin release and degradation
ce:section.ce:para: Ozonation of 1–8 mg L−1 oxidized total microcystin-LR of 16–100% and 9–82% for high- and low-viability Microcystis at 30 min, respectively ( Fig. 4). For high-viability Microcystis, extracellular microcystin-LR increased with 25–275% treated by ozone of 1–4 mg L−1, whereas it was oxidized to below 1 μg L−1 (WHO safety guideline) with an initial concentration of 8 mg L−1 at 8 min (Fig. 4a; 4b). For low-viability Microcystis, ozonation of 1–4 mg L−1 induced an increase of extracellular microcystin-LR (60–116%) at 30 min (Fig. 4c). Strikingly, with an elevated ozonation of 8 mg L−1, extracellular microcystin-LR increased within 5 min, and then, it became decreased to 30 μg L−1 at 30 min (Fig. 4d).

A consecutive reaction could well fit the process of microcystin release and degradation, since almost values of NSE were above 0.80 ( Table 1). Table 1 showed that intracellular microcystin release (k
i ) of low-viability Microcystis (332–534 M−1 s−1) became higher than that of high-viability Microcystis (107–262 M−1 s−1) with equal initial concentrations of ozonation (1–8 mg L−1) (P < 0.05). However, extracellular microcystin degradation (k
e ) of low-viability Microcystis (42–78 M−1 s−1) became lower than that of high-viability Microcystis (90–152 M−1 s−1) (P < 0.05) (Table 1). Interestingly, Δk
toxin (k
i -k
e ) of low-viability Microcystis became much higher than that of high-viability Microcystis (P < 0.05) (Table 1). Besides, average values of k
i , k
e and Δk
toxin (k
i -k
e ) for both high- and low-viability Microcystis exhibited the same pattern with individual ozonation treatment (Table 1).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Mechanism of ozonation to treat Microcystis-laden source waters affected by cell-viability

ce:section.ce:para:
Interestingly, unlike chlorination, there was no significant difference of rate constant for ozone slow decay (k
slow ) between high- and low-viability Microcystis, but chlorination exhibited a higher k
slow of low-viability Microcystis than that of high-viability Microcystis (Li et al., 2020). It might be varied mechanism for this slow oxidant decay between ozonation and chlorination. Li et al. (2020) noted that elevated organics and aromaticity also promoted chlorine slow decay, whist factors involved in ozone slow decay might be complex. On the one hand, reactive organics have been oxidized by ozonation at the fast ozone decay process, and thus, the effects of organics on ozone slow decay process for high- and low-viability Microcystis became weak. On the other hand, ozone decomposed by the formation of radical initiators OH- and HO2- at pH value of 8.0, but the presence of carbonate ions could act as radical scavengers to reduce oxidant decay (Hitzfeld et al., 2000; Rositano et al., 2001; Brooke et al., 2006; Onstad et al., 2007). This study found that source waters dominated by low-viability Microcystis exhibited higher alkalinity than that by high-viability Microcystis (P < 0.05) (Fig. 5). It suggested that elevated carbonate ions could effectively counteract the effects of organics on slow decay process of ozone for low-viability Microcystis.

Ozonation induced membrane destruction of high-viability Microcystis depending on oxidant exposure (Fig. S3), in agreement with a range of previous studies (Table S1). Ozonation was also effective to impair membrane integrity of low-viability Microcystis, and a lower ozone exposure (4 mg min L−1) was sufficient to impair 100% loss of membrane integrity than that for high-viability Microcystis (12 mg min L−1) (Fig. S3). Furthermore, kinetics results certified that k
loss of low-viability Microcystis became much higher than that of high-viability Microcystis, and the same result was also documented for chlorine and potassium permanganate (Li et al., 2020, 2021). Overall, low-viability Microcystis became more susceptible to ozone attack than high-viability Microcystis, but associated mechanism was not well understood by previous studies.

Previous study of Li et al. (2014) noted that gelatinous sheath could protect Microcystis from potassium permanganate oxidation, indicating that cellular surfaces of Microcystis cells was the first barrier to resist ozonation before oxidant attacked cellular membrane. Gelatinous sheath was mainly consisted of a variety of organic matters, such as peptides, polysaccharide etc. (Xu et al., 2013). Microcystis cells were resistant to oxidant attack, since these organic matters as scavengers reacted with oxidant molecular, resulting in a decrease of oxidant exposure. Herein, SEM observation found that gelatinous sheath of low-viability Microcystis became loose compared to high-viability Microcystis ( Fig. 6a), leading to a poor protective response to ozonation. Meanwhile, organic matters extracted from cellular surface of low-viability Microcystis, was much lower than that of high-viability Microcystis (P < 0.05) (Fig. 6b). Hence, compared to high-viability Microcystis, the poor resistance to ozonation by low-viability Microcystis was mainly ascribed to loosely gelatinous sheath comprised with fewer organic matters as oxidant scavengers.

This study only investigated ozonation experiments using unicellular Microcystis cells. However, as we all known, amounts of Microcystis cells could form colonies during a severe bloom in some natural lakes or reservoirs, such as Lake Taihu (China), Lake Erie (USA) etc. (Harke et al., 2016; Tang et al., 2018). These colonies formed by Microcystis cells were mainly glued together via extracellular organics (e.g., polysaccharides, peptides) (Xiao et al., 2019). Compared to colonies consisted of high-viability Microcystis at development stage of a bloom, Microcystis colonies consisted of low-viability cells became disaggregated and declined at decay stage of a bloom, ascribed to a striking reduction of extracellular organics (Tang et al., 2018), as the same finding for unicellular low-viability Microcystis cells observed in this study (Fig. 6b). Overall, the pattern of changed resistance to ozonation by unicellular high- and low-viability Microcystis, was also applicable for natural Microcystis colonies at development and decay stage of a successive bloom.

Sufficient ozonation (>12 mg min L−1) could induce 100% loss of photosynthetic activity of high-viability Microcystis (Fig. 1; S4), in agreement with studies of Wert et al. (2013) and Li et al. (2018) . This study found that a lower ozone exposure (4 mg min L−1) was also effective to completely inactive photosynthetic apparatus of low-viability Microcystis (Fig. 1; S4). Moreover, kinetics studies found that k
inactive of low-viability Microcystis became much higher than that of high-viability Microcystis treated by equal initial concentrations of ozone (Fig. 3). These findings indicated that ozonation was more effective to inactive low-viability Microcystis than high-viability Microcystis even with a lower oxidant exposure, and this finding was not reported by previous studies.

Photosynthetic system was intracellular apparatus of Microcystis. During ozonation, oxidant molecular must destroy cellular membrane, and then, it could further oxidize photosynthetic system (Wert et al., 2013; Li et al., 2018). This study employed SYTOX Green (molecular weight: 509) to determine membrane integrity. Molecular weight of ozone (58) is less than SYTOX Green, suggesting that it can easily destroy photosynthetic system via free diffusion once membrane integrity of Microcystis cells was destroyed. Prior to ozonation, more than 50% loss of membrane integrity was observed for low-viability Microcystis, that was much higher than that for high-viability Microcystis (less than 10%) (Fig. S3). Furthermore, during ozonation, elevated membrane destruction of k
loss was observed for low-viability Microcystis (Fig. 3). These results suggested that ozone molecular became easier to attack photosynthetic apparatus of low-viability Microcystis than that of high-viability Microcystis.

Ozonation induced a higher k
i of microcystin release for low-viability Microcystis than that for high-viability Microcystis (Table 1), in line with k
loss , and the same results were also observed for chlorination and potassium permanganate oxidation (Li et al., 2020, 2021). Previous studies noted that ozonation efficiency in destroying MC-LR was reduced by elevated DOC concentration (Onstad et al., 2007; Miao and Tao, 2009). However, even with elevated ratios of [DOC: ozone], this study found that ke of microcystin degradation for low-viability Microcystis kept lower than that for high-viability Microcystis (Table S2), indicating that elevated organics were not the main factor to reduce microcystin ozonation for low-viability Microcystis. In fact, aromatic compounds could be in competition with MC-LR ozonation (Rositano et al., 2001; Von, 2003; Onstad et al., 2007). This study found that concentration of aromatic organics become higher for source waters dominated by low-viability Microcystis than that by high-viability Microcystis (Fig. 5). Hence, the decrease of k
e of low-viability Microcystis could be ascribed to competitive inhibition by elevated aromatic organics.

Ozonation of organic pollutants has two pathways: direct attack by molecular ozone via cycloaddition or electrophilic reaction, and indirect attack via hydroxyl radicals formed by ozone decomposition (Von, 2003). Onstad et al. (2007) certified both molecular ozone and hydroxyl radicals to oxidize microcystin-LR. This study conducted ozonation experiments at pH value of 8.0, indicating that hydroxyl radicals was formed by hydroxyl ion. Notably, organic matters and carbonate ions were effective scavengers for hydroxyl radicals (Von, 2003; Onstad et al., 2007). This study found that source waters dominated by low-viability Microcystis held higher organic loads and alkalinity than that by high-viability Microcystis (Fig. 5), revealing that microcystin oxidation by hydroxyl radicals could be greatly reduced for low-viability Microcystis and molecular ozonation might become the main mechanism to oxidize microcystin.

Additionally, during ozonation to treat high- and low-viability Microcystis, the pattern of ke< ki was not changed by the decrease of cell-viability (Table 1), in opposite with chlorination (Li et al., 2020). Interestingly, the same result was observed by potassium permanganate oxidation to treat both high- and low-viability Microcystis, while their pattern of ke<ki or ke>ki for both high- and low-viability Microcystis was determined by their initial dosages of potassium permanganate (Li et al., 2021). In this study, ozonation experiments exhibited the same pattern of ke< ki for both high- and low-viability Microcystis in all ozonation treatments (Table 1). Thus, unlike chlorination and potassium permanganate oxidation to treat both high- and low-viability Microcystis, these results demonstrated that the pattern of ke< ki by ozonation could not be affected by both cell-viability and initial ozone dosages.

To further address the difference of microcystin fate between high- and low-viability Microcystis, Δk
toxin (k
i -k
e ) were estimated in each ozonation and the potential of microcystin control became high as this value of Δk
toxin went down (Table 1). For high-viability Microcystis, Δk
toxin was significantly reduced with elevated ozone exposure, and sufficient ozone exposure (>42.4 mg min L−1; 8 mg L−1) oxidized total and extracellular microcystin-LR to below safety guideline (Fig. 1; 4; Table 1). In contrast, a higher ozone exposure (>51 mg min L−1) held a residual oxidant of about 1.7 mg L−1 for 15 min, but it did not achieve this goal for low-viability Microcystis (Fig. 1; 4). Meanwhile, Δk
toxin showed an increasing trend for low-viability Microcystis along with elevated ozone exposure, but the trend was opposite for high-viability Microcystis (Table 1). Overall, a higher microcystin risk would occur for low-viability Microcystis than high-viability Microcystis, mainly due to the increase tread of Δk
toxin at elevated ozone exposure.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Evaluation of ozonation to treat high- and low-viability Microcystis
ce:section.ce:para: This study found that sufficient ozonation (>42.4 mg min L−1, 8 pg per cell) could eliminate microcystin risk for high-viability Microcystis and complete cell inactivation was also gained. Moreover, ozonation can promote post-coagulation to remove high-viability Microcystis (Xie et al., 2013, 2016; Hu et al., 2014). These findings suggested that pre-ozonation process was proper to treat Microcystis-laden source waters dominated by high-viability cells. It must be noted that initial dosages of ozone in practice, was depending on Microcystis biomass (Rositano et al., 1998; Hoeger et al., 2002; Coral et al., 2013), and ozone concentration of < 2 mg L−1 was often used as a pre-oxidant in DWTPs, aiming to reduce negative effects (e.g., metabolites release, disinfection by-products). Consequently, pre-ozonation process could be recommended to treat high-viability Microcystis with a biomass of < 2.5 × 105 cells mL−1.

This study found that photosynthetic inactivation of low-viability Microcystis became higher than that of high-viability Microcystis even with a decrease of ozone expose, treated by the equal initial concentrations of ozone. However, low-viability Microcystis became less resistant to ozonation, leading to an increase of the release of intracellular microcystin (k
i ). Meanwhile, elevated aromatic organics competitively inhibited microcystin ozonation (k
e ), and hydroxyl radicals for microcystin oxidation could be further reduced by elevated organic loads and alkalinity. Overall, the potential of extracellular microcystin control [Δk
toxin (k
i -k
e )] was strikingly reduced by the decrease of cell-viability, and thus, elevated microcystin risk would be the great barrier to limit its application for low-viability Microcystis. These findings would provide important reference of ozonation to treat Microcystis-laden source waters dominated by high- and low-viability cells during a successive bloom.

Xi Li: Experimental design, Writing/revising manuscript, Investigation, Data curation, Conceptualization, Project management., Weijun Song: Investigation, Data curation. Sheng Chen: Investigation, Data curation.

Toxic cyanobacteria are hazards to affect drinking water safety globally, and their cell-viability declines at decay stage of a succussive bloom. This study has elucidated how cell-viability of cyanobacteria affected ozonation to treat cyanobacteria-laden source waters. Results showed that cyanotoxin risk would be the great barrier to limit ozonation application for low-viability cyanobacteria, even with benefits of higher cell inactivation compared to high-viability cyanobacteria. These findings would provide an important reference of ozonation to treat cyanobacteria-laden source waters dominated by high- and low-viability cyanobacteria during a successive bloom.
